You would be better off buying Rust, Rising World, The Forest, and etc. which are in the  same price range and will offer you the same type of game play.

reviewText:
Yet another Digital Homicide makes it onto Steam. (Get it? Ha ha, it's a funny joke.)

As with the other Digital Homicide games on Steam, this would be another interesting idea if the developers would actually put effort into their games and not work on something game-jam worthy and full of $200 asset packs and release it on Steam. However, they don't, and they never do - they basically source everything from Unity Store asset packs, Google Images, and probably elsewhere. Read: they don't make any original content and resell (and steal!) the work of others.

But enough about Digital Homicide themselves, as if you already haven't been deterred from this game yet. Let's talk about the game itself, what this review is supposed to be about. Firstly, it's laggy as hell. It even shows in the trailer for the game! I mean, if you're going to make a game that lags so much, at least try to HIDE it somehow. The developer is straight out with it. Also, only two servers for the game exist, and they're both empty for the most part! When I play an MMO, I expect it to be a MMOG, not a MSOG (Massively Singleplayer Online Game). Finally, a lot of the buggy components from the infamous The Slaughtering Grounds can be found here: the unnecessary achievements, the glitchy pause menu, and the VERY simple inability to capture the mouse, just to name a few.

All I can say is that I can and have made better games than this in two weeks using mostly original content. That makes this load of bull-pucky extremely disappointing as a software developer myself.

reviewText:
You would have noticed that Forsaken Uprising is not on my recommended list! Here my IMHO on Forsaken Uprising (full release).

There is no getting away from it, the graphics aren't going to blow you away even on highest settings. Grass for example will rotate, its hard to explain but if you remember DOOM items/dead humans/enemies would rotate to face you, even when you circled them dead. Well its the same for the grass in FU. Textures aren't up to much either, I'm also not sure what is unity bought assets from the developers own work? So on that point I can't comment on. When all is said and done, I can forgive graphics. It is after all a title that is currently £1.99 on the steam store down from £14.99 if memory serves.

The crafting in Forsaken Uprising, seems the main highlight as there are many items you'll be busy crafting. Not sure on why ground logs and rocks with red glow is the only collectible resources and not standing trees nor rock faces. One corner stone in survival crafting games is how it deals with protecting your hard earned resources, I'll touch on building later but 'hinges' a item for making doors, is a process that requires so many loops to jump through. Doors on the buildings are to my knowledge the only way to hold off new spawn players helping themselves to what is in chests,fires, forges and boxes.

Building a base in which to enjoy and progress through the crafting levels should be a joy. Pillars, floors, walls and roofs are easy to craft but placement can be tricky as walls for example can only face one way and need rotating to stay in place. I needed to jump out of the game 3 times in which to find out, that walls can only be placed one way.

NPCs and combat; Combat is without a doubt the weak link, its like hitting thin air as the npcs just continue their animation attack regardless. Npcs are lifeless and will jump into action only when you get close. All act like you've slept with their wifes and will attack and give chase.

Bugs are what kills the title in the end, it plays very much like a alpha build should not be full release. Killed NPCs dropped chests that will not open most of the time, chests, boxes, fires in fact any item that players work with will and will not open. I can't count the times I had to jump up and down to get a box to open. Food will disappear on fires, items will disappear.

Its ultimately the bugs that will put you off playing, its makes the title not fun at all. In all my 4hrs time I've only been aware of one other player on the server, its been a solo exp for 95% of my time. Lastly I will comment on Digital Homicide normally I wouldn't be reviewing the developers other then on how active they are in a EA game, but it is well documented. The Youtube PR fall out would in my view have magnified the issues present in Forsaken Uprising dooming the title to one to avoid. The game isn't great but its not the worst I have downloaded on my PC. My advice to DH would to firstly fix the bugs, 2nd place a system to protect players items or doors as easy crafted as walls etc and work on the combat system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me tell you a little story before I explain what I like.

I spawn for the first time playing on a hill over looking an NPC village. As I explored my inventory, I found a club! I quickly equipped it, and just in time too!!

Some strange naked (sexless as this is a pg game) man had appeared behind me, so I promptly hit him in the head with my club. Then I ran down the hill to visit the village I found. On the way, I happened to notice I too was naked. So I was hopeful that this nice village would offer me some cloths and an idea on what to do next.

I was approached by a NPC knight, who tried to kill me?!?! Talk about unreasonable, not to let a naked club wielding person into your village. Talk about rude, so I ran past him and further in, hoping to find a helpful hand. But I was met with attacks instead. Everyone in the village was now chasing this naked club holding guy around. I tried to lose them by running around a cow, but it wasn't enough to get away.

10/10 will streak through village again!

Now for the real review. The game is fun and very easy to pickup and figure out without having to deal with 15 minutes plus of boring tutorials.

Beyond that, this game has some great ideas going on here. Build your own castle, make siege equipment, and lay waste to your neighbor's place. There are quests, to do beyond just building. Plus blue prints to unlock for stronger equipment.

All I can say, is remember, this isn't a finished game, there will be bugs, but if you want to help support a game that is well worth it, and you're ready to have fun, even with bugs, then this game is for you!

Hello all!

I've had a lot of fun with this game so far! It deff has some bugs but its alpha and I'm sure they will be worked out, I've noticed the controls seem to be a little different when it comes to moving items in and out of your inventory and into a campfire/forge so at first that is a little frustrating but once you get use to the way it wants you to do that kind of stuff the game pops out and shines in its own ways.

In my encounters I have only found one person that was not friendly, so that's kind of a plus if your coming from a game like rust ware a guy with a rifle will kill you for your epic loot consisting of a rock and some wood.

In short, this is already a game you can get your moneys worth out of especially if you get it on sale like it is right now for $11. Don't get frustrated right away if your having trouble moving things around in you inventory because once you get the hang of it, its well worth it!

reviewText:
It's really just yet another survival game in development. Graphics are like Morrowind. Engine is Unity (so very few game options available). You progress by collecting resources to make the recipes. There doesn't seem to be any permanence because when I logged in, the server was going to reset in 3 days (maybe it resets weekly?).

I've went through the tutorial and it hasn't been accurate a few times. For example, it says you split a stack by ctrl+left click, but it only worked with ctrl+right click (my bindings are all default). Also, it doesn't say you need to press 'f' to start the campfire so I was stuck there watching nothing happen until I went to read a steam guide.

It's not a very well polished game. I wanted to use a windowed mode 4:3 resolution but 800x600 had things overlap and/or unreadable/cut off. I had several FPS drops. There's sudden changes in the lighting/sky when the time passes. It'll be blue skies one moment, then sunset the next. Lakes seem to be pure reflections of the sky (instead of water) and you die if you go into it.

Your health regens very quickly so it usually takes a pack of enemies to kill you (at least when starting out). You can afk with one mob attacking and be fine. Armed with only a club, I could easily take out the armored NPCs hanging around camps. Enemies don't seem to have a leash range so it seems like you can make a train of them follow you to the ends of the earth. And when you die the enemies keep attacking you until you respawn so your health bar goes far into the negatives. There doesn't seem to be a penalty for death (I kept my items).

There is a objective system but the 3 objectives shown were to kill 10 animals, 5 greenskin NPCs (goblins? haven't seen them), or 5 undead NPCs. They each had a time limit and if you fail it just restarts the timer. I'm not sure what happens if you complete them.

I had the most fun letting enemies chase me and trying to collect as many types as possible. I started with a couple bears and a warthog, went to the northeast quadrant and picked up some undead and wolves, travelled to the northwest quadrant and couldn't find anything, then died because I took a phone call and stopped moving for a second too long. If you want to try this, watch out for the ferns and trees: you can run through them but the enemies have to route around them. If you get too far ahead they'll run back home. My sustenance bar never got low enough to find out what happens when you run out (and stamina/strength seem mostly pointless, though they decrease when you run or attack too much).

I was going to say that the server was empty but apparently one guy typed in chat while I was writing this.

I couldn't recommend the game in its current state, there has to be another survival that can give you a similar or better experience. Everything is a work-in-progress but at least the developer hasn't given up on updates yet. It was more fun for me playing to mess with the engine (mob trains, AI, etc.) than to actually grind the resources and do the recipes. Maybe a try if you're the type of person who wants to mess around in an unbalanced and somewhat buggy/incomplete game.

---

Edit: Today when I logged in the screen was mostly black and I couldn't see more than the UI. Relaunched several times and it finally worked after I changed resolution. There also seem to be some inventory/crafting bugs where items randomly disappear when moving them or aren't crafted. It was pretty annoying because it doesn't refund your materials. There's another bug where I couldn't gather any more wood until I respawned. And sometimes you can't open chests/pick up items.

On a similar note, it also allows you to 'craft' when you don't have the required materials, so you are just watching a progress bar do nothing. In addition, the inventory doesn't let you stack more than 200 wood/stone. However, if you try to create a stack of exactly 200 it will roll over and you'll end up with 1. (For example, combine 192 stone with 8 stone and you end up with one stack of 1 stone). And if move an item onto a slot that is about to receive an item (for example: if you're mining stone in the background while checking your inventory) then the item you're moving will disappear.

Also, I forgot to mention that (at least in windowed mode) your mouse isn't captured by the game when you check your inventory or alt-tab. And recaptured when you exit inventory. If you find you can't attack/place items and it shows a mouse cursor, you probably need to open and close your inventory to attack. You can also take advantage of this: if you hold your mouse button while opening the inventory, you'll keep attacking until you close the inventory and retake control of the mouse.

The AI/health regen in this game allows you to easily kite mobs. If you want to grind the quests (which give 50 divinity each- divinity unlocks more crafting recipes) then walk in the middle of a fort/settlement and then move in a circle around them while attacking. I held s+d (to move back and to the right) while attacking and moving my mouse slightly to the left. Eventually they'll die and if you do it properly there shouldn't be any danger unless you get stuck on something.

Death animations are pretty funny because most of the time there is no animation (the model suddenly hovers above the ground in a standing position then the model lowers to the ground where a chest appears.) However, for some deaths it allowed you to hit them as they were hovering and they'll ragdoll backwards before disappearing.
